highlights.text: AT A GLANCE    Scientific Foresight: What if?    What if generative artificial intelligencebecame conscious?    Generative artificial intelligence applications, such as ChatGPT, are powered through complex learning processesby comprehensive datasets of  potentially dubious  human-created content. There are concerns that such toolscould develop consciousness and spark emergent behaviour that is, by definition, unpredictable

Generative AI applications that use models based on neural networks to identify patterns and structureswithin existing data to generate new and original content have become very popular, but alsocontroversial, with the recent deployment of new versions of ChatGPT and other new large language modelsLLM. While artificial intelligence in general has been the focus of attention and the subject of legislativework at EU level for some time, the release of new generative systems has shown that technological change

title: E2E encryption and protection of children online
snippet: End-to-end encryption (E2EE) systems bring enhanced security advantages to private communications. Yet they also pose increased difficulties to law enforcement investigations. In the case of child sexual abuse (CSA) online, these systems hide data from children who are being abused or coerced into sexual abuse, leading to a failure to pursue these crimes. Reports of online grooming increased by 82 % in 2022. While E2EE might prevail for all its advantages, it is also necessary to protect young children and avoid a drop in online CSA abuse reports as major technology companies plan to move towards this technology. An EU legislative proposal aims to combat the rise in online CSA including grooming while protecting and not compromising E2EE systems.

news.reference_string: E2EE systems have been increasingly popular since 2016 when WhatsApp encrypted its network. These systems improve the privacy and security of communications by using cryptography through an algorithm that transforms standard text characters into an unreadable format, securing communications from one endpoint to another. This explains the general trend in recent years for online community forums, chat rooms and messaging apps to E2E-encrypt their participants/members' communication exchanges. Thus business documents, financial details, legal proceedings and/or personal conversations including photos, videos or livestreamed material can be protected more effectively. However, E2EE alone does not guarantee privacy or security, as data may be held unencrypted on the user's own device, or be accessible if the login is compromised. Other uses of E2EE, in addition to securing communication, include better protection of passwords and data storage. E2EE also supports internet freedom and democracy as it makes censorship and surveillance harder. As countries implement legislation to prevent not only illegal but also other harmful content online, digital platforms might see E2EE as a solution, as companies cannot moderate encrypted online content and be liable for it if they cannot technically access it. Some see this as one of the reasons why social media platforms want to promote E2EE, in addition to improving their users' privacy. Conversely, industry representatives and civil society groups expressed concern that to avoid E2EE, social media platforms could take steps that create unacceptable, negative impacts on users' privacy as a way to provide proactive moderation of private online spaces while scanning and assessing the content of conversations. Another related issue is the definition of what constitutes a 'private communication' today. Traditionally, private communication included mainly one-to-one phone calls or messages. Today, digital platforms enable many participants to take part in an online videoconference or in chat groups, sometimes with thousands of users (WhatsApp communities for instance allow for up to 2000 users). Meanwhile, E2EE is not immune to cyber-attacks. Although E2EE can secure data against them more effectively, cyber-attacks are becoming more sophisticated with the help of artificial intelligence (AI), and some experts believe that the developments in quantum technology will further expose its security vulnerabilities to crack E2EE. https://www.wired.com/2016/04/forget-apple-vs-fbi-whatsapp-just-switched-encryption-billion-people/https://www.ibm.com/topics/end-to-end-encryptionhttps://losspreventionmedia.com/end-to-end-encryption-doesnt-guarantee-internet-privacy/https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-66099040https://petsymposium.org/popets/2023/popets-2023-0060.pdf https://www.europarl.europa.eu/thinktank/en/document/EPRS_BRI(2020)659360 https://euipo.europa.eu/ohimportal/en/-/news/social-media-discussion-paper-published https://nas.io/blog/setup-whatsapp-communities https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/08839514.2022.2037254 https://www.protocol.com/enterprise/quantum-computing-algorithms-encryption-vulnerabilities https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/are-quantum-computers-about-to-break-online-privacy/

Children are increasingly using the internet. Global estimates reveal that one in three children is an internet user, and that one in three internet users is under 18 years of age. Children are also increasingly accessing the internet from mobile devices. However, according to some research, just a third of parents are aware of the correct minimum age requirement for social-media use. Moreover, younger children have no problem bypassing the EU age requirements contained in the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and put in place by services such as social media, which require a 13-year age limit for their users (or 16 for WhatsApp). This failing has resulted in significant fines for some social media such as the Meta group and TikTok. https://www.unicef-irc.org/growing-up-connectedhttps://www.ofcom.org.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0024/234609/childrens-media-use-and-attitudes-report-2022.pdf https://www.europarl.europa.eu/thinktank/en/document/EPRS_ATA(2023)739350 https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A02016R0679-20160504&qid=1688555780407 https://www.politico.eu/article/instagram-fined-e405m-for-violating-kids-privacy/ https://ico.org.uk/about-the-ico/media-centre/news-and-blogs/2023/04/ico-fines-tiktok-127-million-for-misusing-children-s-data/

title: Stress-testing to promote the resilience of EU policies
snippet: Stress-testing is a promising foresight policy tool that can support the design of EU policies able to withstand the shocks and challenges of both the present day and the years to come. This study explores how the European Parliament could use stress-tests to identify weak points in EU legislation and avenues for further EU action. The study draws on the findings of a stress-test of EU rail transport policy and recommendations from an expert practitioner of foresight and regulatory policy. It finds that stress-tests across different policy areas could boost the European Parliament's role as co-legislator in the European Union, especially in the agenda-setting and law-making phases of the legislative cycle.
